question: Do antibiotic-induced alterations of the gut microbiome decrease colonization resistance to Clostridium difficile and increase susceptibility to infection? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Antibiotics can have significant and long-lasting effects on the gastrointestinal tract microbiota, reducing colonization resistance against pathogens including Clostridium difficile.
content.source_2: In a randomized crossover trial of healthy adults receiving a 3-day course of a narrow-spectrum antibiotic, stool microbiome profiling and ex vivo colonization assays showed rapid recovery without diminished colonization resistance; C. difficile spore germination and vegetative growth were reduced relative to pre-treatment samples.
content.source_3: Our results indicate that antibiotic-mediated alteration of the gut microbiome converts the global metabolic profile to one that favours C. difficile germination and growth.
content.source_4: Contrary to expectations, post-antibiotic metabolomics revealed increased levels of secondary bile acids that suppress C. difficile germination, and antibiotic-treated mice exhibited lower infection rates than untreated controls over a 2-week observation period.
